The Palestinian Authority becomes the 123rd member of the International Criminal Court. The move gives the court jurisdiction over alleged crimes in Palestinian territories. Israel and the United States opposed the Palestinians' efforts to join the court.

Theia is a one-year-old bully breed mix who was hit by a car and buried in a field. She managed to stagger to a nearby farm, dirt-covered and emaciated, where she was found by a worker. She suffered a dislocated jaw, leg injuries and a caved-in sinus cavity.

Mohammad Javad Zarif received a hero's welcome as he arrived in Iran on a sunny Friday morning. He has been U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry's opposite number in securing a breakthrough in nuclear talks that could lead to an end to sanctions against Iran. But there are some facts about Zarif that are less well-known.

The five were exposed to Ebola in Sierra Leone in March, but none developed the deadly virus. They are clinicians for Partners in Health, a Boston-based aid group. One of the five had a heart-related issue and has been discharged but hasn't left the area.

A Duke student has admitted to hanging a noose from a tree, university officials say. The school says the student is no longer on campus and will face student conduct review. The student was identified during an investigation by campus police and the office of student affairs.

Trey Moses was originally going to take his girlfriend to his high school prom. Ellie Meredith, a freshman with Down syndrome, has struggled with friendships since elementary school. "You just feel numb to those moments raising a special needs child," Ellie's mom says.

Amnesty International's annual report catalogs the use of state-sanctioned killing as a punitive measure across the globe. On one hand, the number of executions worldwide has gone down by almost 22% on the previous year. At least 607 people were executed worldwide in 2014, compared to 778 in 2013.

Andrew Getty appears to have died of natural causes, police say. The coroner's preliminary assessment is there was no foul play involved in Getty's death. Andrew Getty was found on his side near a bathroom in his home, KTLA reports.

Tropical storm Maysak is heading west in the Pacific Ocean. It's expected to make landfall Sunday morning on the southeastern coast of Isabela province. Authorities are taking preemptive steps to keep people safe.

Bob Barker returned to "The Price Is Right" for the first time in eight years. The 91-year-old hosted the show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007. Barker handled the first price-guessing game of the show's classic "Lucky Seven"

Yahya Rashid, a UK national from northwest London, was detained at Luton airport on Tuesday. He's been charged with engaging in conduct in preparation of acts of terrorism. Rashid is due to appear in Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.

Paul Walker died in November 2013 at the age of 40 after a car crash in Los Angeles. The actor was one of the nicest guys in Hollywood. "He was a person of humility, integrity, and compassion," a friend says.

Researchers re-examined archives of the Red Cross, the International Training Service and the Bergen-Belsen Memorial. They concluded that Anne and Margot Frank probably did not survive to March 1945. Days at the camp were filled with terror and dread, witnesses said.

Mike Pence is drawing huge heat for his controversial decision to sign a religious freedom law last week that opens the door to discrimination against gays and lesbians. The Indiana governor has scored a lot of points this week among ultraconservatives.

The late Whitney Houston set the modern standard for the national anthem at Super Bowl XXV. Roseanne Barr may have established the low-water mark. Jimi Hendrix inflamed mainstream America with his psychedelic take on the anthem. Michael Bolton belts it out, but there's one little problem -- the words.

Walmart is emerging as a bellwether for shifting public opinion on hot-button political issues that divide conservatives and liberals. Former Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlenty says Walmart's actions "foreshadow where the Republican Party will need to move"

Amnesty International releases its annual review of the death penalty worldwide. In Pakistan, the government lifted a six-year moratorium on the execution of civilians in the wake of the Taliban attack on a school in Peshawar in December. Jordan, Iran and Iraq executed people for "terrorism," and other countries expanded the scope of capital crimes in their penal codes. A sharp spike in death sentences recorded in 2014, up more than 500 on the previous year.

French prosecutor says he is not aware of any video footage from on board Germanwings Flight 9525. Two magazines, German daily Bild and French Paris Match, claim to have found a cell phone video of the harrowing final seconds of the plane's final moments. An official with France's accident investigation agency, the BEA, says the agency is not.

The Rev. Robert H. Schuller was diagnosed with esophageal cancer in August 2013. He was also the founder of Crystal Cathedral megachurch in California. He sold a softer, gentler message, which borrowed heavily from the father of the feel-good gospel.

Michele Bachmann compares President Obama to the co-pilot of the doomed Germanwings flight. Bachmann: "With his Iran deal, Barack Obama is for the 300 million souls of the United States what Andreas Lubitz was for the 150 souls on the German Wings flight"
Louis Jordan, 37, had been on the 35-foot Pearson sailboat for more than two months. He left Conway, South Carolina, to fish in the ocean after a storm capsized his boat and broke his mast.

U.S. and its negotiating partners reached a strong framework agreement with Iran on Thursday. Peter Bergen: The deal limits Iran's nuclear program in such a way as to effectively block it from building a nuclear weapon.

California is a breadbasket to the nation, growing more than a third of its vegetables and nearly two-thirds of its fruits and nuts. A strong dollar allows producers to import crops that may be withering under the absence of rain or other misfortunes elsewhere in the U.S.
Keonna Thomas, 30, also known as "Young Lioness" and "Fatayat Al Khilafah," is charged with trying to fight for ISIS. She's one of three women arrested this week on terror charges.

Iranian authorities imposed the ban on women attending men's sports events after the Islamic Revolution in 1979. It's not clear exactly which games women will be able to attend. FIFA President Sepp Blatter called on Iran last month to end its "intolerable" ban.

Dissident blogs, YouTube channels, social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter have emerged as alternative to mainstream media. The lack of access to print and broadcast media in authoritarian countries is driving force leading disaffected voices to post online. Singapore's use of the courts to bring libel and defamation cases, usually carrying heavy financial penalties, is preferred method of silencing discomfiting online voices.

Avril Lavigne says she was bedridden for five months after contracting Lyme disease. "I thought I was dying," she tells People magazine. Lavigne is releasing a new single this month to support the 2015 Special Olympics.

The Fury 325 is the tallest and fastest "giga-coaster in the world. Mike Tyson lived in a gaudy, abandoned Ohio mansion in the 1980s and '90s. Penn Jillette was part of a panel on Indiana's religious freedom law.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says he sees better options than "this bad deal or war" "I think there's a third alternative, and that is standing firm, ratcheting up the pressure until you get a better deal," Netanyahu says. Democrats and Republicans spar over the Iran nuclear deal.

Indiana pizzeria is at center of debate over state's Religious Freedom Restoration Act. Owner: "If a gay couple was to come and they wanted us to bring pizzas to their wedding, we'd have to say no" Critics say the new law would allow businesses to discriminate against gays and lesbians.

Authorities in Malegaon, India, have asked residents to take a'mugshot' of their cattle and submit it to the police. Police officials believe this is the only way to solve cow slaughter cases and enforce the law.
It's hard to swallow the idea of a single person being stranded at sea for days, weeks, if not months and somehow living to talk about it. Miracles do happen, though, and not just in Hollywood.

The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is the largest particle accelerator in the world. The LHC generates up to 600 million particles per second, with a beam circulating for 10 hours, traveling more than 6 billion miles. It took thousands of scientists, engineers and technicians decades to devise and build the particle accelerator.

Kevone Charleston, 36, is suspected of involvement in 32 commercial robberies dating to November 2013. He was shot and wounded by FBI agents and task force officers, but his injuries are not life threatening, sheriff's deputy says.

People west of the Mississippi River will have the best view of the eclipse. It started at 3:16 a.m. Pacific Daylight Time, when the moon began moving into Earth's shadow. The total eclipse will only last four minutes and 43 seconds, NASA says.

Somalia-based Al-Shabaab has been behind a string of recent attacks in Kenya. The terrorist group is predominantly driven by the same radical interpretation of the Koran as al-Qaeda and ISIS. The attack is another step in the ongoing escalation of the terrorist group's activities.

Easter is a cornerstone event in the Christian faith. It celebrates the completion of Christ's mission of salvation in the Crucifixion and Resurrection. Unlike Christmas, it doesn't fall on the same day every year but shifts around in spring.

The NCAA says it has no legal responsibility to ensure the academic integrity of courses offered to student-athletes at its member institutions. "They seem to talk out of both sides of their mouths," a former athletic-academic director says.

A Connecticut teen forced to have chemotherapy to treat Hodgkin lymphoma will remain in temporary custody of the state. The 17-year-old is in remission after nearly six months of forced chemo treatments. A Connecticut juvenile court judge issued a written decision denying a motion to let the teen go home.

"Uptown Funk!," featuring Bruno Mars, is the longest-leading Billboard Hot 100 of the 2010s. It's also just the 10th single in the Hot 100's entire history to spend at least 13 weeks at No. 1. "Funk" passes Robin Thicke's "Blurred Lines," featuring T.I. and Pharrell.

Antarctica recorded the temperature (15.5 degrees Celsius) on March 24. The temperature was recorded at Argentina's Esperanza Base on the northern tip of the Antarctica Peninsula. The World Meteorological Organization is in the process of setting up an ad-hoc committee.

Indiana's new Religious Freedom Restoration Act faces a firestorm from critics. Critics say it uses faith as a pretext to discriminate against gay people. So far, 20 states have some version of the religious liberty law, and the legal controversies have grown.
Robert Lewis Burns Jr. was part of the genre-defining Southern rock band Lynyrd Skynyrd. He was not restrained at the time of the crash, a Georgia State Patrol spokesman says.

Man accused of stabbing U.S. Ambassador Mark Lippert in Seoul last month is charged with attempted murder. Kim Ki-Jong has also been charged with assaulting a foreign envoy and business obstruction. Kim's trial must begin within 14 days of receiving indictment.

A former banker, 29-year-old Briton Rurik Jutting, was charged with two counts of murder. A court hearing that was to determine whether there was enough evidence to proceed to trial was adjourned until May.

Thai Airways subsidiary Thai Smile unveils colorful new livery featuring characters from "Adventure Time" The airline is a subsidiary of Thailand flag carrier Thai Airways. The inaugural flight takes place on April 4, heading from Bangkok to Phuket.

Chelsea Manning appears to have joined Twitter this week. Manning is serving a 35-year prison sentence for leaking thousands of classified documents. The former Army intelligence analyst was convicted of stealing and disseminating 750,000 pages of documents to WikiLeaks.

Frida Ghitis: Reaching a good, solid agreement with Iran is a worthy, desirable goal. She says the process has unfolded under the destructive influence of political considerations, weakening America's hand and strengthening Iran. Ghitis says Obama has a huge political stake in these negotiations.
"Furious 7" is poised to nab the biggest opening of 2015 to date. It will easily beat the $121.9 million launch of "The Hunger Games Mockingjay — Part 1" in November.

Deion Sanders Jr. is a wide receiver at Southern Methodist University. He has gone on record with his love for "hood doughnuts," or confections from "a place in the hood" His father reminded him he has a trust fund, condo and clothing line.

An outside review by Columbia Journalism School professors concluded that an "institutional failure" at Rolling Stone resulted in a "deeply flawed" article. Ruben Navarrette: Can UVA, Phi Kappa Psi or any of the other fraternities on campus sue for defamation? He says Virginia Supreme Court said in Jordan v. The government of Shibuya ward, one of Tokyo's most famous shopping districts, passed ordinance on Wednesday paving the way for "partnership certificates" for same-sex couples. The certificates will not be issued until later in the summer and are not legally binding.

Listeria was found in a cup of Blue Bell ice cream from the Broken Arrow, Oklahoma, plant. The company is shutting down the plant "out of an abundance of caution," the company says. The warning does not affect other Blue Bell products made at the plant.

Defense Minister Gen Nakatani says Japan's jets have never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs. Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler-turned-lawmaker, had asked if aircraft were scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats.

Fighting has killed hundreds in Yemen in less than two weeks. The Red Cross has cried out for a humanitarian ceasefire to let aid into Yemen. More than 50 people died in Aden on Monday, Agence France-Press reports.

David Lynch has confirmed he will no longer direct the revival of "Twin Peaks" He said he felt the network was not offering enough money to produce the show "the way it needed to be done" The cult 1990s television show was set to return in 2016.

Kentucky guard Andrew Harrison apologized for the "poor choice of words" he muttered after losing to Wisconsin. Harrison said his words were "in jest," and that he meant no disrespect to Frank Kaminsky, who is white.

Malaysian bomb maker Zulkifli bin Hir was killed in January raid in the Philippines. FBI had been offering $5 million reward for information leading to Marwan's capture. He was believed to be a member of southeast Asian terror group Jemaah Islamiyah's central command.

Paramedics were called last week to a rented villa at the Sirenusa resort in St. John after the family of four fell ill. The use of methyl bromide is restricted in the United States because of its acute toxicity. The U.S. Department of Justice has initiated a criminal investigation.

Chris Rock tweeted a series of tweets documenting three traffic stops in seven weeks. "Stopped by the cops again wish me luck," he posted early Tuesday. Many African-Americans have long bemoaned being pulled over for no apparent reason.

Six people injured in explosion at chemical plant in China's southeastern Fujian province. Plant produces a reportedly carcinogenic chemical used in production of polyester films and fabrics. Plant was slated for Xiamen, but was relocated to a more remote location in 2007.

A 15-count indictment has been filed in federal court in California against FedEx. Frida Ghitis: It turns out a corporation can indeed be prosecuted like a person. She says it's a practice the Supreme Court has approved of for over a century. Ghitis asks: Should FedEx be held liable for "possessing" what bad guys may send through the service?

Mark Wahlberg will star in a film about the Boston Marathon bombing and the manhunt that followed. "Patriots' Day" is being produced by CBS Films. The film will be told from Boston Police Commissioner Ed Davis' point of view.

Model Manuela Arbelaez accidentally revealed the correct answer to a guessing game for a new Hyundai Sonata. Host Drew Carey couldn't stop laughing as he exulted with the right answer. It's been a busy week for the game show.

Carlos Colina, 32, arraigned on charges of assault and battery causing serious bodily injury and improper disposal of a body. Police were notified Saturday about a suspicious item along a walkway in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Surveillance video led them to an apartment building, where more body parts were discovered.

"Arrested Development" executive producer Brian Grazer said the show will return for a fifth season of 17 episodes. The fourth season was streamed exclusively on Netflix in 2013 after Fox canceled the show several years before.

"Mad Men" has become a symbol of the times -- his and, sometimes, ours. The show about a 1960s advertising agency and its collision with changing times has become part of the national fabric. It's reasonable to assume the new season will pick up soon afterward.
"Vampire Diaries" star Nina Dobrev announced she will be leaving the show at the end of this season. "I always knew I wanted Elena's story to be a six season adventure," Dobrev said.

Education minister Smriti Irani was visiting a FabIndia outlet in the tourist resort state of Goa. She spotted a security camera overlooking the changing room of one of the stores, police say. The arrested staff have been charged with voyeurism and breach of privacy.
The group included four children -- the oldest being 10 or 11, with the youngest born in 2013, a Turkish official says. The nine were arrested at the Turkey-Syria border, the Turkish military says.

A nuclear submarine being repaired at a Russian shipyard caught on fire, state-run news agency reports. "The submarine is in a dry dock," a law enforcement source says. The fire began on a sub in the Zvyozdochka shipyard in northwestern Russia.

Kayahan was one of Turkey's best-loved singers and songwriters. He was diagnosed with cancer in 1990, the year he competed in the Eurovision Song Contest. He died Friday in a hospital in Istanbul, five days after his 66th birthday.

Zhou Yongkang is the highest-ranking Chinese Communist Party official ever to face corruption charges. He was expelled from the Communist Party and arrested last December. Zhou was one of nine men who effectively ruled the country of more than 1.3 billion people.

In the New Testament, money gets 37 mentions, while "gold" gets 38 citations, "silver" merits 20, and "copper" four. Jesus told his Twelve Apostles to follow him on an itinerant mission with few prospects of success and no visible means of support. Jesus and his disciples walked, wore what they had, slept outside or stayed in friends' homes.

Three people were killed and five others wounded in an attack on the attorney general's office in Balkh province. Most staff members and civilians have been rescued, but an exchange of fire between Afghan security forces and assailants is ongoing.

Rand Paul has tried to sell himself as a different type of Republican, Sen. Rand Paul's campaign team told reporters last week that his campaign announcement message would be about "expanding the Republican Party" Paul has also questioned the Civil Rights Act, and even claimed that private business owners have a right to discriminate.

TV5Monde is gradually regaining control of one of its 11 channels and social media accounts. The outage began around 8:45 p.m. Paris time on Wednesday. ISIS logos and markings appeared on social media pages of the network.
American Jennifer Stewart says she was devastated to learn that Etihad Airways lost her pet cat. The 2-year-old cat, Felix, went missing on a flight from Abu Dhabi to New York.

In Louisville, Kentucky, Sen. Rand Paul announces he will run for president. In Chicago, voters will head to the polls in a very surprising runoff between Mayor Rahm Emanuel and challenger Jesus "Chuy" Garcia. In Ferguson, Missouri, the shadow of Michael Brown and the protests over his shooting by Officer Darren Wilson will loom large.

The fire broke out at the General Electric Appliance Park in Louisville, Kentucky. There were no reports of anyone injured or trapped. The park is large such that 34 football fields could fit in one of its warehouses.

Ted Cruz is hoping to energize Iowa's evangelical base. Cruz is the only official contender in the 2016 presidential race. The senator from Texas is hoping Iowa will be his prize in a crowded field of candidates.

The hashtag #147 notjustanumber refers to the number of people killed at Garissa University College. Kenyan churches mourned the dead during Easter services Sunday as armed guards protected the congregations.

Most of the penalty amounts to forced spending on improving pipeline safety. A section of PG&E pipeline exploded in San Bruno, killing eight people and injuring more than 50 others. The previous record penalty was a $146 million penalty against Southern California Edison Company in 2008.

Jurors found Dzhokhar Tsarnaev guilty of all 30 counts in the Boston Marathon bombing trial. Seventeen of the 30 counts were capital charges, meaning he is eligible for the death penalty. The trial will move into a penalty phase, where the jury will hear testimony and arguments from both sides.

Mexican state oil company Pemex says 45 workers were injured in the blaze. Two of them are in serious condition, the company says. Authorities evacuated about 300 people from the platform after the fire started. The fire had been extinguished by Wednesday night.

John Sutter: Easter is about how religious impulses, and patterns, operate in ways that affect our lives. Easter Triduum refers to the three days of Easter that begin with Good Friday, proceed through Holy Saturday and Easter Sunday.

Police in Lucknow, northern India, have bought four pepper-spraying drones for crowd control. The unmanned aircraft will be fitted with a camera and pepper spray; each drone costs between $9,560 and $19,300. Some are concerned about the suppression of freedom of speech.

A female employee accused Xavier Morales, a supervisor within the agency, of assault after he made sexual advances at her. This is just the latest chapter for an organization embroiled in scandal over the past several months.

Investigators are not expected to return to the crash site, a French national police official says. The plane crashed March 24 in rugged terrain of the Alps about 6 miles (10 kilometers) from the town of Seyne-les-Alpes.

April 8 was also "Rex Manning Day" Twitter paid homage to the 1995 film "Empire Records" The movie centers on an independent record store in Delaware where, on April 8, former pop idol Manning is scheduled to make an appearance.
Twisted Sister's 2016 tour is being titled "Forty and F*ck It" "It's official: Farewell," Twisted Sister singer Dee Snider posted on Facebook. The band will play with a new drummer, Mike Portnoy.

Nicole Kidman's "Grace of Monaco" will premiere on Lifetime on Memorial Day, May 25. The film was directed by Olivier Dahan and focuses on a period in the early '60s when Monaco was involved in a stand-off over taxes with France. Dahan lashed out at TWC's Harvey Weinstein, over the movie's final cut.

One person is killed in Fairdale, Illinois, in the rural Illinois hamlet of Fairdale. A video surfaced on YouTube of a massive twister barreling across an open field, barely missing farmhouses and barns. Hail stones the size of tennis balls plummeted down on Ashton, Illinois.

Witness says he didn't see Walter Scott grab Slager's Taser. Officer Michael Slager has been fired and charged with murder in the death of 50-year-old Walter Scott. Slager initially said he used a Taser on Scott, who, Slager said, tried to take it.

Kanye West and photographer Daniel Ramos filed a civil suit against the hip-hop star. West pleaded no contest last year to a misdemeanor count of battery over the scuffle. Ramos and his lawyer, Gloria Allred, sought general and punitive damages.

Don McLean's pop masterpiece "American Pie" sold for $1.2 million to an unnamed buyer. McLean was a paperboy when Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens and J.P. "The Big Bopper" died in a plane crash in 1959. There is magic brewing in the music and words of "American Pupils"

Mary Kay Letourneau Fualaau was a married teacher and mother of four in 1996 when she began an affair with her 13-year-old student. She went on to serve more than seven years in prison on charges related to their sexual relationship. On Friday, ABC's "20/20" will air an interview with the couple.

"American Pie" has become one of the most dissected and argued-about songs in pop music canon. The draft that was auctioned is 16 pages: 237 lines of manuscript and 26 lines of typed text. It includes lines that didn't make the final version as well as extensive notes.
Vijay Chokalingam applied to medical school claiming to be African-American. Mindy Kaling's brother, Vijay, says he posed as a black man to gain admission to prestigious schools.

"I've been so happy with my (Scientology) experience in the last 40 years that I really don't have anything to say," Travolta says. The actor is one of the Church of Scientology's most high-profile members along with Tom Cruise and Kirstie Alley.
